title: 115_s1371
content: The "Working Families Tax Relief Act of 2017" strengthens the Earned Income Tax Credit. The "Working Families Tax Relief Act of 2017" enhances the Earned Income Tax Credit by increasing the credit for individuals with no qualifying children. The table in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to raise the credit amounts significantly. The "Working Families Tax Relief Act of 2017" increases the Earned Income Tax Credit for individuals with no children by amending the table in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to raise credit amounts significantly. Section 32(c)(1)(A)(ii) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to change the age requirement from 25 to 21. These amendments will be effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2016. The Child Tax Credit is being strengthened. The Child Tax Credit is being increased for taxpayers with young children. The credit amount for qualifying children under 6 years old is $3,000, and for those over 6 years old, it is $1,000. The Child Tax Credit is being increased for taxpayers with young children. For qualifying children under 6 years old, 45% of earned income is refundable, and for those over 6 years old, it is 15%. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2016. SEC. 4. Indexing the child tax credit for inflation. Inflation adjustments are made to dollar amounts in the Internal Revenue Code for taxable years after 2017, based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year. Increases are rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. The amendment made by this section will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2017, and dollar amounts in the Internal Revenue Code will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. SEC. 5. Simplifying the Earned Income Tax Credit. Modification of Abandoned Spouse Rule under Section 32(c)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows certain married individuals living apart with a qualifying child to qualify for tax benefits. The modification of the Abandoned Spouse Rule under Section 32(c)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 states that individuals with a legally binding separation agreement and not living with their spouse by the end of the taxable year will not be considered married for tax purposes. Amendments to the code clarify the definition of marriage in this context. Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to eliminate the Disqualified Investment Income Test by striking subsection (i) and making conforming amendments. This includes adjustments to rounding dollar amounts in subsection (b)(2)(A) to the nearest multiple of $10. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to simplify rules for claiming the Earned Income Tax Credit without a qualifying child if the child is claimed by another family member. The amendment simplifies rules for claiming the Earned Income Tax Credit without a qualifying child if the child is claimed by another family member. If an individual is claimed as a qualifying child by an eligible individual, any other eligible individual without a qualifying child may still be considered eligible for the credit. The amendment simplifies rules for claiming the Earned Income Tax Credit without a qualifying child if the child is claimed by another family member. An eligible individual without a qualifying child may still be considered eligible for the credit. The amendment simplifies rules for claiming the Earned Income Tax Credit without a qualifying child if the child is claimed by another family member. Effective after December 31, 2016, an individual without a qualifying child may still be eligible for the credit.
